claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination significantly expands the repertoire of tumor antigens presented on MHC-I molecules.

evidence.quote: Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination
Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape

claims.caveat: Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.

claims.claim: The ability of intratumoral mRNA vaccination to sensitize tumors to immune checkpoint blockade is strictly dependent on the induction of Type I interferon signaling.

evidence.quote: Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors
Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.

claims.caveat: Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: Combination therapy involving mRNA vaccination and ICI promotes an inflammatory state characterized by increased CD8+ T-cell infiltration and PD-L1 expression.

evidence.quote: PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x | 1.0x | Checkpoint axis became more targetable
Intratumoral CD8+ T-cell density fold-change | 1.8x | 1.0x | Increased immune infiltration with combination therapy

claims.caveat: Vaccine-only treatment did not produce durable tumor control in non-immunogenic models.

claims.claim: Patients who had received a prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination showed an improved survival outcome when subsequently treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI).

evidence.quote: Human retrospective metastatic cohort: 130 patients total.
Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
